description._content: The Other Voices Table The table includes a series of porcelain tree sculptures. Awry and gnarled, the porcelain tree trunks are riddled with arborglyphs, delivering messages that speak of human behavior, while conveying both distress and conviction. Appropriated phrases include "We are ugly but we are here," (a coded response adopted by oppressed Haitians to signal hope amidst desperate circumstances) and “Those who haven’t seen this world would never believe it,” (from the diary of Rutka Laskier, a Jewish teenager from Poland who chronicled three months of her life during the Holocaust). The uprooted porcelain trees reinforce a symbolic sense of struggle, both physical and psychological, emphasizing all the various biblical, political, cultural, economic and personal scenarios imaginable. The Brooklyn Ball 2011 celebrates the art, creativity, and influence of Brooklyn artists and the Museum’s role as a cultural gateway. This year’s Ball is being designed in partnership with Brooklyn artists to create an evening filled with art, ideas, and surprises. Felicia Wong photo, Brooklyn Museum
